ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: #1 The readings are useful but there are quite a bit of them every week.#8 The professor is extremely knowledgeable but explanations of conceptual material were hard to follow at times.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Exposure to theories about the policy process, wide range of coastal topics that were explored, and an assignment that challenged us to apply policy analysis techniques.

I liked that we covered a lot of different topics in the coastal arena. While I think we tried to do too much, I appreciate how everyone likely saw their favorite topic at some point in the class. I also liked being walked through the policy writing process. I think the expectations for each of these assignments could have been better explained but the walk through was great.I also liked working on a final project with a group. I'm all for collaborative projects since that's what we'll see in the professional world.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Course discussion. Get rid of the student presentations! A number of presents simply listed off the details of article without synthesis or thought.

The use of the time spent in class could be improved. Students are expected to summarize papers but feel like some of the connections between papers, bigger themes, and conceptual theories could be better explained.

1) WAY TOO MUCH READING MATERIAL. A number of the papers were redundant or unnecessarily vague/dense/unhelpful. Reading are important for this class but I would like to see readings chosen with a better eye for clarity/conciseness/usefulness, not simply with the aim to fill a set number of pages to read per week. Quality over quantity please!2) Need to totally redesign the class format. There are SO many ways this class could have been better conducted. The material is incredibly important, especially for those of us who have no other place at FES to learn about these topics, but I found myself totally regretting taking this class due to the format.-having each paper assigned to a student and then having each of us summarize our paper, one after the other, day after day, with little guidance/discussion generation from Prof. Burroughs, just resulted in me leaving class each day with a vague idea of the topics we were supposed to gain. At least have one student present all papers (fewer papers per day please!) on a given topic so at least THEY can synthesize the material if Prof. Burroughs doesn't want to.-Everyone learns differently. This class only worked for those who are good at processing large amounts of dense reading. Vary the ways that material is taught and you'll engage ALL your students, notjust a few.3) Field trips and guest speakers please! We are RIGHT on the coast with many great field trips option and interesting people working on coastal issues within a close drive- let's make use of that! Class variety is important, especially for people who might learn better with hands-on/face to face interactions, rather than straight reading all semester.4) The lack of focus on international topics meant that literally half of the people shopping the class in January walked out during the first class meeting. I recognize that there are lots of issues one could cover but Prof. B does have international experience and he should bring that to the classroom.5) Please don't make us use CATME again please =(6) Would be great to have the exam right before spring break with ALL the non-project-related topics and then focus on the final project for the rest of the semester, with no final exam. It was kind of a weird, disjointed evaluation schedule.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: N/A

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: Important to coastal planning/gov career

While I don't plan on necessarily going into the policy field, I am interested in coastal issues and think understanding the policies that shape government and regulatory actions (or inactions) on these issues is extremely valuable.
This is the work I want to focus on post-FES. A fair amount of it was review but it's good to feel like I have updated and expanded my knowledge.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: Interest
See answer to question 17.
This is my primary interest in grad school and FES have very few other coastal classes.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: To some degree but could be improved. Too much reading without synthesis.

Yes and no. I think that the collaborative group project design is a good one but I didn't feel the feedback was as helpful as I had hoped for. At this point at the end of the course, I do not feel completely confident in being able to apply policy analysis techniques to an independent project. I do think the complexity of these issues was apparent from taking this courseand it gave me new insight to understanding the political (as opposed to scientific) side of coastal issues.
No, see previous questions.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Good since it mirrors the real woldl. Disadvantage - the CATME exercise should be eliminated. I do not believe I should be given the chance to "rat out" my teammates or for them to voice their displeasure at having to work hard. In the real world nobody cares and this type of evaluation should be left "unsaid."

It was not always easy to coordinate schedules. In addition, since the instruction wasn't always clear, it was difficult to come to consensus on an approach to take to the project. As a result, I think the final product suffered in continuity.
Always good to work in groups as that's what we'll see in the professional world.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: To make the most of this course, you have to commit to doing the readings and asking lots of questions in class to clarify when you aren't following something or don't understand.

Carefully consider what material is being taught your particular semester as Prof. B changes the main project each year. Also pay attention to the class format/expectations. If there is not a dramatic change from this year (Spring 2014), I probably wouldn't suggest taking the class. There's a lot of potential for this class as Prof. B really knows what he's talking about but he needs to reimagine what this class could be in the future.
